Award.AwardTitle: DMREF: Collaborative: Computationally Driven Discovery and Engineering of Multiblock Polymer Nanostructures Using Genetic Algorithms
Award.AbstractNarration:
****Technical Abstract****
This computationally driven discovery program aims to disrupt the status quo for the design of multiblock materials. The research centers on the marriage of pseudo-spectral self-consistent field theory (SCFT) and real-space genetic algorithms (GAs), with a tight coupling to experimental synthesis and characterization. While widely used in polymer science and bioinformatics, respectively, SCFT and GAs have not been previously integrated to tackle problems of block polymer discovery and design. The approach adopted here addresses the challenges of large parameter spaces and polymorphism. It also solves the "inverse problem" of identifying multiblock sequences and compositions that can produce a desired nanoscale morphology, without resorting to exhaustive, unguided searches through parameter space. The computational effort is synergistically and iteratively combined with an experimental program that includes state-of-the-art synthesis, processing, and characterization tools. The experimental work will validate the computational methodology, including parameterization of the models, and provide inspiration for attractive and synthetically accessible design targets. This combined approach will dramatically reduce the timescale for discovery, design, and deployment of new multiblock polymers as advanced functional materials.

****Non-Technical Abstract****
This collaborative effort between researchers at the University of California, Santa Barbara and the University of Minnesota will develop discovery tools that will enable the rational, computationally-assisted design of multiblock polymers for applications in medicine, microelectronics, separations, and energy production and storage, among others. Complicating factors in this class of soft materials are the myriad parameters that dictate molecular architecture, block sequence, and interactions and the wide range of self-assembled nanostructures that are possible. Through a concerted and iterative combination of theory, simulation, and experiment, global optimization tools will be devised and validated to predict the forward and reverse relationship between polymer architecture and nanostructure. The discovery tools developed in this program will be made widely available to the industrial and academic polymer materials community through a web-based job submission program hosted at the Minnesota Supercomputer Institute, and a searchable database will be constructed from the structure/sequence/morphology maps that result over the course of the project. Outreach to industry will be accomplished by leveraging the established and highly successful industrial consortiums at UCSB (Complex Fluids Design Consortium) and UMN (IPrime). Personnel on the project will be trained in and enhance the rich multidisciplinary research environments afforded by the existing MRSECs at UMN and UCSB.
This award is funded by the Division of Materials Research (DMR) and the Division of Mathematical Sciences (DMS).

POR.DRECONTENT:
Polymers consist of many repeat units of a chemical building block connected into long chains. The physical properties of a polymer are dictated by the chemistry of those building blocks (known as monomers). For example, some polymers are rubbery while others are glassy, and many commercially important polymers can crystallize. In a block polymer, two (or more) polymers are connected by their ends to make an inhomogeneous material. This approach provides the opportunity to impart multiple physical properties into the same material, for example combining a rubbery and a glassy behavior. Equally important, as most polymers do not want to mix, melts of block polymers typically undergo a microphase separation. The polymers cannot completely demix, since the different chemistries are bonded at their ends, and block polymers thus produce ordered structures with length scales between about 5 and 50 nanometers.

Modern synthetic chemistry methods now enable the construction of a bewildering number of possible combinations of block polymers using an enormous palette of possible monomers. The complexity of the number of possibilities increase rapidly as the number of blocks and number of monomers increases. While the simplest block polymer (a diblock) with two blocks and two types of monomers has only one possible combination, a tetrablock terpolymer (4 blocks, 3 monomer types) has 9 possible combinations and a block polymer with 6 blocks and 4 monomer types has 300 possible combinations! The complexity is only further increased by noting that these are just the ways the blocks can be arranged; there are also many possible choices for the monomers and the relative amounts of each block. Thus, the problem in materials design has shifted from “What can we make?” to “What should we make?” Moreover, an approach of synthesizing all of the possible combinations and seeing what happens is infeasible.

The design of block polymers is ideally suited for a materials genome approach, where theoretical analysis guides the selection of what materials to synthesize and characterize. This project took advantage of a rigorous theoretical framework for predicting the phase behavior of block polymers, known as self-consistent field theory (SCFT), and applied it to the discovery of new ordered phases in both diblock polymers and tetrablock terpolymers. Of particular interest is the discovery of new tetrahedrally-close-packed, Frank-Kasper phases in both types of materials, including the first report of Laves phases in diblock polymers. Frank-Kasper phases are remarkably complex, consisting of many nominally spherical particles per unit cell with a relatively open structure. Frank-Kasper phases are commonly found in metals, in particular in alloys, but have recently been discovered in a number of soft materials including surfactants and liquid crystals. The materials discovery activities undertaken during this project required a materials genome approach, as the theoretical results guide experiments, the results from which are then fed back to the theory to improve the parameter estimation and help explain puzzling results.

In addition to demonstrating the power of a materials genome approach to materials discovery, this project also provided new tools to the research community to implement this approach in their own research. The key effort in this direction was the development and release of the “Broadly Accessible Self-Consistent Field Theory” package (http://pscf.cems.umn.edu) and related documentation and examples. While many fields of materials science have commercially available software to guide experiments, no such software existed for block polymer phase behavior. The Broadly Accessible SCFT software ameliorates this problem, providing a platform that can be used by either experimentalists or theoreticians working in this area. The project also provided improvements in the implementation of SCFT that enable the study of complex phases, like Frank-Kasper phases.

This project involved the training of postdoctoral researchers, graduate students, and undergraduate students in all aspects of the project, ranging from polymer synthesis to characterization to simulation. Importantly, the project was tightly integrated between these different aspects, with frequent theory/experiment collaboration and co-authoring, allowing students to gain a breadth of exposure that would not be possible in a single-PI research project.
